profile.name: Rich Harris
profile.bio: NYC-based software dev 💻 | Building & breaking things, learning loudly 🚀 | JS, React, Go, Cloud. Occasional hot takes on frontend. #SoftwareDevelopment

tweets.content: Is it really debugging if you're just staring at the screen hoping the bug will feel awkward and leave?
Huge thanks to everyone who contributes to open source, even the smallest typo fix or docs improvement. It all adds up and makes a difference. You're appreciated!
Just checked out Bun's new test runner. Looks incredibly promising for fast feedback loops in dev. Excited to see where this goes. #JavaScript #DevTools
The next 'disruption' in frontend might not be a new framework, but a build tool so optimized it makes current dev servers feel sluggish. The compiler is the new runtime.
Just spent an hour debugging a build error only to realize I was on the wrong branch. My brain needs a `git checkout --my-brain` command.
Looking back at old code, it's easy to cringe. But it's also a reminder of how much we learn and grow. Continuous improvement isn't just for software.
Reading up on CRDTs again. Fascinating how robust distributed systems can be built with such elegant mathematical foundations. My head hurts in a good way.
Playing around with some new CSS Houdini features today. The possibilities for animating custom properties are really interesting. Definitely worth diving deeper.
Sometimes I think the biggest advancements in dev tooling aren't new features, but the subtle improvements in error messages and feedback loops. DX is everything.
Reminder to take breaks. The code will still be there, but your brain might not be if you push too hard. Step away, recharge. Your future self will thank you.
Saw the news about `:has()` landing in stable in more browsers. Love seeing continued innovation in core web platform features. It's the bedrock we build on. #CSS
Good API design is like a well-written sentence: clear, concise, and unambiguous. Bad API design is like a compiler error in Klingon.
We've settled into a rhythm with frameworks, but I still believe the next big leap will come from rethinking core compilation and reactivity paradigms, not just more syntactic sugar.
Often, the best performance optimization isn't clever code, but avoiding work entirely. Think about *why* you're doing something, not just *how*.
My favorite part of any standup is the moment someone inevitably says 'I just need to fix one small thing...' and then disappears for the rest of the day.
Experimenting with WebAssembly for a tiny utility today. The startup costs are still a hurdle for some use cases, but the potential is undeniable for others. #WebAssembly
Interesting read on the economics of OSS. The sustainability challenge is real and complex, no easy answers. We need more models than just 'volunteers and corporate sponsorship'.
The challenge of open source isn't just writing code, it's writing documentation, triaging issues, and saying 'no' gracefully. It's a marathon, not a sprint.
